awd_titl_txt: OPUS:  CRS:  Integrating organismal biology into the geographic mosaic of coevolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies a predator-prey arms race between toxic newts and the garter snakes that eat them.  The coevolutionary dynamics that push arms races such as this one onward are determined by many factors. The coevolutionary dynamics may involve the geographic distributions of the species, the physiological effects of toxins, or the structure of proteins that are used in attack or defense. Synthesizing how these different levels of biological organization interact and dictate arms races will help us better predict outcomes of coevolutionary battles. Understanding what drives one enemy to outpace the other, or eventually win the race, can inform strategies for managing interactions between humans and disease, hosts and parasites, and plants and their herbivore pests. 

This synthesis of several integrative studies will explore the connections between landscape ecology, microevolution processes, and underlying genetic and protein variation. Previous work on these newts and snakes has amassed thousands of physical specimens with associated phenotypic, genetic, and spatial data spread across multiple labs and collections. The proposed synthesis activities will aggregate these resources into a single relational database. These data will be used in spatially explicit analyses to test predictions about the historical, ecological, and environmental factors that structure geographic mosaics of coevolution. The intersection of organismal mechanisms and evolutionary process will be explored in a single-authored popular science book that follows the pathways to discoveries within the newt-snake system. The book will focus on how natural history observations led to hypotheses, and how tests of those ideas in turn generated new questions to pursue. Additional products include the publicly accessible database, three new papers from spatially explicit analyses, and a series of educational video trailers that introduce evolutionary concepts to high school audiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award support the aggregation, cleanup and organization of a 25+ year dataset describing one of the textbook examples of predator-prey coevolution - TTX toxicity of newts and resistance to the same toxin in snake predators. The assembly of a single, publicly available data set that collects integrative studies on physiology, morphology, genetics, and ecology represents a valuable resource for scientists who work to uncover the relationships between different scales of biological organization from protein structure to geographic landscapes. The database includes over 4000 observations from 126 different localities across western North America, and represents the work of 6 collaborating laboratories. Data are publicly available in CSV formats in open-access repositories, or in the form of a relational filemaker database on request. The database will be actively curated into the future, adding new data annually.

These archival data were used to explore landscape patterns of variation in traits at the phenotypic interface of the arms race between predators and prey. Two unexpected results emerged from analyses of this database that could only be detected with this kind of broad scale data. First, climate contributes to the landscape patterns of variation in arms race phenotypes, above and beyond the effects of biological interactions. Second arms-race phenotypes (ie, levels of prey toxin and predator resistance) are exaggerated in areas with a higher diversity of interacting species. Snake resistance and newt toxicity phenotypes were most extreme in environments characterized by weak seasonality, and favorable climate during activity periods for snakes (spring-summer) and newts (winter) also promoted the evolution of exaggerated arms race traits. We found TTX resistance to be higher in environments with more newt species, and toxicity was elevated in environments with more snake species. These patterns suggest the underlying abiotic conditions that structure how, where, and when species engage in coevolutionary interactions may reinforce the dynamics of arms race coevolution. The relationship between arms race phenotypes and ecological variation suggests the spatial structure of coevolutionary mosaics is quite sensitive to broader ecological processes that facilitate the biotic interaction between natural enemies.

Short educational videos on coevolutionary concepts using newts and snakes were delayed because of pandemic imposed constraints. Plans to continue that component are in place using other sources of funding.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/19/2023
Modified by: Edmund D Brodie
